title: A Luminescent Microporous Metal–Organic Framework with Highly Selective CO
Adsorption and Sensing of Nitro Explosives
abstract: A luminescent microporous metal−organic framework based on a triphenylene-2,6,10-tricarboxylate ligand, which exhibits highly selective CO
gases and selective sensing of the nitro explosive 2,4,6-trinitrophenol, has been constructed and characterized.
A luminescent microporous metal–organic framework based on a π-electron-rich tricarboxylate ligand and an In
ion has been solvothermally obtained and characterized and exhibits highly selective CO
gases and selective sensing of the nitro explosive 2,4,6-trinitrophenol.
text: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been extensively researched during the past decade for their structural diversity and potential applications in gas storage and separation, magnetism, catalysis, and molecular sensing.
Recently, MOFs have emerged as excellent sorbents for CO
capture and storage because of their advantages such as high surface area, tunable pore size, and low crystal density,
particularly for the usage of selective capture of CO
Until now, only a few porous MOFs have shown highly selective adsorption of CO
over other gases such as CH
and the construction of viable CO
-capture MOF materials that can exhibit high CO
still remains a challenge. On the other hand, MOFs combining luminescence and permanent porosity have been of particular interest because of their potential applications as chemical sensors.

The rapid sensing of nitro explosives present in soil and groundwater is very crucial for security screening, homeland security, and environmental monitoring. The luminescence quenching method has proven to be a simple, sensitive, and convenient method for the sensing of such explosives.
Herein, we report a luminescent microporous MOF, (Me
and selective sensing of the nitro explosive 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP).

exhibits strong emission at 505 nm at ambient temperature upon excitation at 410 nm (Figure S9 in the

), with a quantum yield of 3%, which prompts us to explore its application for the detection of electron-withdrawing compounds such as nitro explosives. Fluorescence quenching titrations were performed by adding

shows the quenching of luminescent intensities upon the addition of methanol solutions of TNP (0–2 mM). The maximum fluorescent intensity of

Moreover, there is an obvious red shift (from 505 to 537 nm for the maximum fluorescent emission) for the spectra accompanied by quenching of the luminescent intensity upon the addition of a 2 mM methanol solution of TNP, which can be ascribed to the guest-dependent interactions between the MOF host framework and TNP (kinetic diameter ca. 7.2 Å).
On the other hand, the luminescence responses of
to other nitro explosives, such as 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 2,6-dinitrotoluene (2,6-DNT), and nitrobenzene (NB), were ascertained by dispersing
in 2 mM nitro explosives in methanol (Figure

was reduced by 41.7, 62.1, 73.5, and 65.9% upon exposure to 2 mM methanol solutions of TNT, 2,4-DNT, 2,6-DNT, and NB, respectively. The efficient quenching by nitro explosives can be attributed to a photoinduced electron transfer from the excited framework of
(as an electron donor) to the adsorbed electron acceptor (nitro explosives).
However, unlike TNP, the maximum fluorescent emission of
was hardly shifted by TNT, 2,4-DNT, 2,6-DNT, and NB, indicating that
could be regarded as a potential material for the selective detection of the nitro explosive of TNP.
by the addition of 2 mM methanol solutions of TNP, TNT, 2,4-DNT, 2,6-DNT, and NB.
In conclusion, a 3D luminescent microporous MOF based on triphenylene-2,6,10-tricarboxylate has been constructed. The compound exhibits highly selective gas adsorption for CO
, recommending the possible applications in purification of natural gas by CO
from flue gases. Furthermore, it also shows selective sensing of the nitro explosive TNP, making it a promising sensing material for TNP monitoring.

Synthesis and characterization, gas sorption measurements, additional structure figures, adsorption isotherms, adsorption selectivity and luminescenct profiles, isosteric heat isotherms, TGA, PXRD, and X-ray crystallographic data in CIF format. Formation of a Metal-Organic Framework with High Surface Area and Gas Uptake by Breaking Edges Off Truncated Cuboctahedral Cages
Yun, Ruirui; Lu, Zhiyong; Pan, Yi; You, Xiaozeng; Bai, Junfeng

The prepn. and properties are discussed of NJu-Bai9 a product of Zn(NO3)2, BCP (3,5-bis(4-carboxyanilino-carbonyl)pyridine), and DMF in a fluoroboric acid soln.  The crystal structure, surface area and adsorption properties are described.
Porous coordination polymers based on three planar rigid ligands
Zhong, Di Chang; Lu, Tong Bu

A review.  During the last two decades, porous coordination polymers (PCPs), usually called as metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), were developed rapidly due to their versatile structural diversities and potential phys. and chem. functions.  This article provides a short review of recent advances in the design and constructions of porous coordination polymers based on three planar rigid ligands, including imidazole-4,5-dicarboxlate (H3IDC), 1H-tetrazole (HTz), as well as 1H-tetrazole-5-carboxylate (H2Tzc).  Their prepns., crystal structures, and desirable properties were reviewed.
Zirconium-Metalloporphyrin PCN-222: Mesoporous Metal-Organic Frameworks with Ultrahigh Stability as Biomimetic Catalysts
Feng, Dawei; Gu, Zhi-Yuan; Li, Jian-Rong; Jiang, Hai-Long; Wei, Zhangwen; Zhou, Hong-Cai
Zirconium-metalloporphyrin PCN-222 mesoporous metal-org. frameworks with ultrahigh stability as biomimetic catalysts are discussed.
A Chiral Porous Metal-Organic Framework for Highly Sensitive and Enantioselective Fluorescence Sensing of Amino Alcohols
Wanderley, Marcela M.; Wang, Cheng; Wu, Chuan-De; Lin, Wenbin
Journal of the American Chemical Society

A highly porous and fluorescent metal-org. framework (MOF),(I), was built from a chiral tetracarboxylate bridging ligand derived from 1,1'-bi-2-naphthol (BINOL) and a cadmium carboxylate infinite-chain secondary building unit.  The fluorescence of I can be effectively quenched by amino alcs. via H-bonding with the binaphthol moieties decorating the MOF, leading to a remarkable chiral sensor for amino alcs. with greatly enhanced sensitivity and enantioselectivity over BINOL-based homogeneous systems.  The higher detection sensitivity of I is due to a preconcn. effect by which the analytes are absorbed and concd. inside the MOF channels, whereas the higher enantioselectivity of I is believed to result from enhanced chiral discrimination owing to the cavity confinement effect and the conformational rigidity of the BINOL groups in the framework. 1 was quenched by four chiral amino alcs. with unprecedentedly high Stern-Volmer consts. of 490-31200 M-1 and enantioselectivity ratios of 1.17-3.12.
Actuation of Asymmetric Cyclopropanation Catalysts: Reversible Single-Crystal to Single-Crystal Reduction of Metal-Organic Frameworks
Falkowski, Joseph M.; Wang, Cheng; Liu, Sophie; Lin, Wen-Bin

A pair of interpenetrated and non-interpenetrated metal-org. frameworks (CMOFs) using a redox active ruthenium/salen-derived dicarboxylate bridging ligands have been synthesized.  The synthesized RuIII/salen MOFs underwent unprecedented reversible single-crystal to single-crystal redn./reoxidn.  The redn. of the RuIII CMOFs turned on the catalytic activity, and the resulting RII CMOFs were highly active for the asym. cyclopropanation of substituted alkenes with very high diastereo- and enantioselectivities.
Interconversion between Discrete and a Chain of Nanocages: Self-Assembly via a Solvent-Driven, Dimension-Augmentation Strategy
Liu, Tian-Fu; Chen, Ying-Pin; Yakovenko, Andrey A.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Using a ligand bearing a bulky hydrophobic group , a shish kabob of nanocages of copper(II) 5-(triisopropylsilylethynyl)isophthalate, was assembled through either a 1-fell-swoop or a step-by-step procedure by varying the dielec. const. of the assembly mixt.  A hydrophobic solvent breaks down the chain to discrete nanocages, while a hydrophilic solvent reverses the procedure.  Although the shish kabob of nanocages has exactly the same chem. compn. and even the same Archimedean-solid structure as those of its discrete analog, its gas-adsorption capacity is remarkably improved because assembly of a chain exposes the internal surface of an individual cage.  This dimension-augmentation strategy may have general implications in the prepn. of porous materials.
Gated Channels in a Honeycomb-like Zinc-Dicarboxylate-Bipyridine Framework with Flexible Alkyl Ether Side Chains
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Covalent functionalization of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) with methoxyethoxy groups induces conformational freedom in this mol.  Applying these 2,5-disubstituted 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) derivs. in metal-org. framework synthesis together with 4,4'-bipyridine as coligand yields novel honeycomb-like structures [Zn2L2P], (1; H2L = 2,5-bis(2-methoxyethoxy)-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BME-bdc); P = 4,4'-bipyridine (bipy)), {[Zn2(ME-bdc)2(bipy)]n(DMF)2.3(EtOH)0.4} (2; H2ME-bdc = 2-(2-methoxyethoxy)-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid), [Zn2(BMP-bdc)2(bipy)]n (3; H2BMP-bdc = 2,5-bis(3-methoxypropoxy)-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid) and [Zn2(BB-bdc)2(bipy)]n (4; H2BB-bdc = 2,5-bis(n-butoxy)-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid).  The cylindrical channels of these materials are populated with flexible groups, which act as mol. gates for guest mols.  This allows highly selective sorption of CO2 over N2 and CH4.
Carbon Dioxide Capture in Metal-Organic Frameworks
Sumida, Kenji; Rogow, David L.; Mason, Jarad A.; McDonald, Thomas M.; Bloch, Eric D.; Herm, Zoey R.; Bae, Tae-Hyun; Long, Jeffrey R.

An extensive review is given on progress made in the capture of CO2 from power plant emissions, briefly considering also the CO2 storage (sequestration) of the enormous quantities of CO2 that would be obtained as a result of a successful capture framework.  The main existing CO2 capture technologies are discussed in the context of capture performance considerations of aq. alkanolamine solns. and porous solids such as zeolites and activated carbons.  Schematic diagrams are presented of idealized temp. swing adsorption, pressure swing adsorption, and vacuum swing adsorption processes for regenerating solid adsorbent in a fixed-bed column.  The structural features and CO2 adsorption characteristics of isoreticular metal-org. frameworks (MOF) are discussed in detail.  The high-pressure adsorption capacities of 36 MOF and the lower-pressure adsorption capacities of many more MOF, at 293-319 K, are tabulated.  The various types of functionalities that have been explored to date for prepg. materials with enhanced CO2 capture performance are outlined, including amines, strongly polarizing org. functionalities, and exposed metal cation sites.  The synthesis of continuous films of MOF and their use in membranes for gas sepn. are examd., with the tabulation of the CO2 sepn. performance of MOF mixed-matrix membranes.  A final section outlines main issues that need to be addressed to achieve next-generation materials capable of fulfilling the criteria required for the gas sepns. relevant to post-combustion CO2 capture, pre-combustion CO2 capture, and oxy-fuel combustion.
Tunable Rare-Earth fcu-MOFs: A Platform for Systematic Enhancement of CO2 Adsorption Energetics and Uptake
Xue, Dong-Xu; Cairns, Amy J.; Belmabkhout, Youssef; Wojtas, Lukasz; Liu, Yunling; Alkordi, Mohamed H.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed
Journal of the American Chemical Society

A series of fcu-MOFs based on rare-earth (RE) metals and linear fluorinated/non-fluorinated, homo/heterofunctional ligands were targeted and synthesized.  This particular face-centered cubic-metal org. frameworks (fcc-MOF) platform was selected because of its unique structural characteristics combined with the ability/potential to dictate and regulate its chem. properties (e.g., tuning of the electron-rich RE metal ions and high localized charge d., a property arising from the proximal positioning of polarizing tetrazolate moieties and fluoro-groups that decorate the exposed inner surfaces of the confined conical cavities).  These features permitted a systematic gas sorption study to evaluate/elucidate the effects of distinctive parameters on CO2-MOF sorption energetics.  Our study supports the importance of the synergistic effect of exposed open metal sites and proximal highly localized charge d. toward materials with enhanced CO2 sorption energetics.
Development and Evaluation of Porous Materials for Carbon Dioxide Separation and Capture

A review.  The development of new microporous materials for adsorption sepn. processes is a rapidly growing field because of potential applications such as carbon capture and sequestration (CCS) and purifn. of clean-burning natural gas.  In particular, new metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) and other porous coordination polymers are being generated at a rapid and growing pace.  The authors address the question of how this large no. of materials can be quickly evaluated for their practical application in carbon dioxide sepn. processes.  Five adsorbent evaluation criteria from the chem. engineering literature are described and used to assess over 40 MOFs for their potential in CO2 sepn. processes for natural gas purifn., landfill gas sepn., and capture of CO2 from power-plant flue gas.  Comparisons with other materials such as zeolites are made, and the relationships between MOF properties and CO2 sepn. potential are investigated from the large data set.  In addn., strategies for tailoring and designing MOFs to enhance CO2 adsorption are briefly reviewed.
Fine-Tuning Pore Size by Shifting Coordination Sites of Ligands and Surface Polarization of Metal-Organic Frameworks To Sharply Enhance the Selectivity for CO2
Du, Liting; Lu, Zhiyong; Zheng, Kaiyuan; Wang, Junyi; Zheng, Xin; Pan, Yi; You, Xiaozeng; Bai, Junfeng
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Based upon the (3,6)-connected metal-org. framework {Cu(L1)·2H2O·1.5DMF}∞ (L1 = 5-(pyridin-4-yl)isophthalic acid) (SYSU, for Sun Yat-Sen University), iso-reticular {Cu(L2)·DMF}∞ (L2 = 5-(pyridin-3-yl)isophthalic acid) (NJU-Bai7; NJU-Bai for Nanjing University Bai group) and {Cu(L3)·DMF·H2O}∞ (L3 = 5-(pyrimidin-5-yl)isophthalic acid) (NJU-Bai8) were designed by shifting the coordination sites of ligands to fine-tune pore size and polarizing the inner surface with uncoordinated N atoms, resp., with almost no changes in surface area or porosity.  Compared with those of the prototype SYSU, both the adsorption enthalpy and selectivity of CO2 for NJU-Bai7 and NJU-Bai8 have been greatly enhanced, which makes NJU-Bai7 and NJU-Bai8 good candidates for postcombustion CO2 capture.  Notably, the CO2 adsorption enthalpy of NJU-Bai7 is the highest reported so far among the MOFs without any polarizing functional groups or open metal sites.  Meanwhile, NJU-Bai8 exhibits high uptake of CO2 and good CO2/CH4 selectivity at high pressure, which are quite valuable characteristics in the purifn. of natural gases.
Porous materials with optimal adsorption thermodynamics and kinetics for CO2 separation

Nugent, Patrick; Belmabkhout, Youssef; Burd, Stephen D.; Cairns, Amy J.; Luebke, Ryan; Forrest, Katherine; Pham, Tony; Ma, Shengqian; Space, Brian; Wojtas, Lukasz; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Zaworotko, Michael J.

Energy costs assocd. with the sepn. and purifn. of industrial commodities (e.g., gases, fine chems., fresh water) currently represent ∼15% of global energy prodn.; the demand for such commodities is projected to triple by 2050 (P. Taylor, 2010).  The challenge of developing effective sepn. and purifn. technologies which have much smaller energy footprints is greater for CO2 than for other gases; in addn. to its involvement in climate change, CO2 is an impurity in natural gas, biogas (biomass-based natural gas), syngas (CO/H2, the main H2 source for refineries), and many other gas streams.  In the context of porous cryst. materials which can exploit equil. and kinetic selectivity, size selectivity and targeted mol. recognition are attractive characteristics for CO2 sepn. and capture, as exemplified by 5A and 13X zeolites (J. Merel, et al., 2008), and metal-org. materials (MOM).  This paper reports that a crystal engineering or reticular chem. strategy which controls pore functionality and pore size in a series of MOM with coordinately satd. metal centers and periodically arrayed hexafluorosilicate anions (SiF52-) enables a kinetics and thermodn. sweet spots offering high volumetric uptake at low CO2 partial pressure (<0.15 bar).  Most importantly, such MOM offer an unprecedented CO2 sorption selectivity over N2, H2, and CH4, even in the presence of moisture.  Thus, these MOM are relevant to CO2 sepn. in the context of post-combustion (flue gas, CO2/N2), pre-combustion (shifted synthesis gas stream, CO2/H2), and natural gas upgrading (natural gas clean-up, CO2/CH4).
Microporous metal-organic framework with potential for carbon dioxide capture at ambient conditions
Xiang Shengchang; He Yabing; Zhang Zhangjing; Wu Hui; Zhou Wei; Krishna Rajamani; Chen Banglin

Carbon dioxide capture and separation are important industrial processes that allow the use of carbon dioxide for the production of a range of chemical products and materials, and to minimize the effects of carbon dioxide emission.  Porous metal-organic frameworks are promising materials to achieve such separations and to replace current technologies, which use aqueous solvents to chemically absorb carbon dioxide.  Here we show that a metal-organic frameworks (UTSA-16) displays high uptake (160 cm(3) cm(-3)) of CO(2) at ambient conditions, making it a potentially useful adsorbent material for post-combustion carbon dioxide capture and biogas stream purification.  This has been further confirmed by simulated breakthrough experiments.  The high storage capacities and selectivities of UTSA-16 for carbon dioxide capture are attributed to the optimal pore cages and the strong binding sites to carbon dioxide, which have been demonstrated by neutron diffraction studies.
A Robust Molecular Porous Material with High CO2 Uptake and Selectivity
Nugent, Patrick S.; Rhodus, Vanessah Lou; Pham, Tony; Forrest, Katherine; Wojtas, Lukasz; Space, Brian; Zaworotko, Michael J.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The authors report on MPM-1-TIFSIX, a mol. porous material (MPM) based upon the neutral metal complex [Cu2(adenine)4(TiF6)2], that self-assembles through a hydrogen-bonding network.  This MPM is amenable to room-temp. synthesis and activation.  Gas adsorption measurements and ideal adsorbed soln. theory selectivity predictions at 298 K revealed enhanced CO2 sepn. performance relative to a previously known variant as well as the highest CO2 uptake and isosteric heat of adsorption yet reported for an MPM.  MPM-1-TIFSIX is thermally stable to 568 K and retains porosity and capacity even after immersion in water for 24 h.
Polyamine-Tethered Porous Polymer Networks for Carbon Dioxide Capture from Flue Gas
Lu, Weigang; Sculley, Julian P.; Yuan, Daqiang; Krishna, Rajamani; Wei, Zhangwen; Zhou, Hong-Cai

Porous polymer networks prepd. by polymn. of tetrakis(4-bromophenyl)methane with subsequent functionalization by chloromethylation and reaction with diethylenetriamine had high photochem. and thermal stability, high CO2 adsorption capacity and low regeneration costs.
Post-synthetic Structural Processing in a Metal-Organic Framework Material as a Mechanism for Exceptional CO2/N2 Selectivity
Bloch, Witold M.; Babarao, Ravichandar; Hill, Matthew R.; Doonan, Christian J.; Sumby, Christopher J.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The synthesis and ceramic-like processing of a new metal-org. framework (MOF) material, [Cu(bcppm)H2O], that shows exceptionally selective sepn. for CO2 over N2 (ideal adsorbed soln. theory, Sads = 590) is reported.  [Cu(bcppm)H2O]·xS was synthesized in 82% yield by reaction of Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O with the link bis(4-(4-carboxyphenyl)-1H-pyrazolyl)methane (H2bcppm) and shown to have a two-dimensional 44-connected structure with an eclipsed arrangement of the layers.  Activation of [Cu(bcppm)H2O] generates a pore-constricted version of the material through concomitant trellis-type pore narrowing (b-axis expansion and c-axis contraction) and a 2D-to-3D transformation (a-axis contraction) to give the adsorbing form, [Cu(bcppm)H2O]-ac.  The pore contraction process and 2D-to-3D transformation were probed by single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction expts.  The 3D network and shorter hydrogen-bonding contacts do not allow [Cu(bcppm)H2O]-ac to expand under gas loading across the pressure ranges examd. or following re-solvation.  This exceptional sepn. performance is assocd. with a moderate adsorption enthalpy and therefore an expected low energy cost for regeneration.
Enhanced carbon dioxide capture upon incorporation of N,N'-dimethylethylenediamine in the metal-organic framework CuBTTri
McDonald, Thomas M.; D'Alessandro, Deanna M.; Krishna, Rajamani; Long, Jeffrey R.

High capacity, high selectivity, and low-cost regeneration conditions are the most important criteria by which new adsorbents for post-combustion CO2 capture will be judged.  The incorporation of N,N'-dimethylethylenediamine (mmen) into H3(Cu4Cl)3(BTTri)8 (CuBTTri; H3BTTri = 1,3,5-tri(1H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)benzene), a H2O-stable, triazolate-bridged framework, is shown to drastically enhance CO2 adsorption, resulting in one of the best performing metal-org. frameworks for CO2 sepn. reported to date.  High porosity was maintained despite stoichiometric attachment of mmen to the open metal sites of the framework, resulting in a BET surface area of 870 m2 g-1.  At 25° under a 0.15 bar CO2/0.75 bar N2 mixt., mmen-CuBTTri adsorbs 2.38 mmol CO2 g-1 (9.5%) with a selectivity of 327, as detd. using Ideal Adsorbed Soln. Theory (IAST).  The high capacity and selectivity are consequences of the exceptionally large isosteric heat of CO2 adsorption, calcd. to be -96 kJ mol-1 at zero coverage.  IR spectra support chemisorption between amines and CO2 as one of the primary mechanisms of uptake.  Despite the large initial heat of adsorption, the CO2 uptake was fully reversible and the framework could be easily regenerated at 60°, enabling a cycling time of just 27 min with no loss of capacity over 72 adsorption/desorption cycles.
A Miniaturized Linear pH Sensor Based on a Highly Photoluminescent Self-Assembled Europium(III) Metal-Organic Framework
Harbuzaru, Bogdan V.; Corma, Avelino; Rey, Fernando; Jorda, Jose L.; Ananias, Duarte; Carlos, Luis D.; Rocha, Joao

A miniaturized prototype for pH sensing in the pH range 5-7.5 has been constructed from a photoluminescent Eu3+ metal-org. framework that contains two different Eu3+ sites and self-assembles through hydrogen bonding and π-π interactions.  This material has a very high quantum yield and an excellent balance between absorption, energy transfer, and emission rate.
A Luminescent Metal-Organic Framework as a Turn-On Sensor for DMF Vapor
Li, Yu; Zhang, Shanshan; Song, Datong

Herein we report a luminescent lanthanide metal-org. framework (LnMOF) displaying efficient turn-on triggered by solvent vapors, with excellent selectivity for DMF vapor.  The LnMOF was the needle-shaped crystals of [Eu2L3(H2O)4]•3DMF (I) (L = 2',5'-bis(methoxymethyl)-(1,1':4',1''-terphenyl)-4,4''-dicarboxylate ) can be obtained in high yield by heating a soln. of Eu(NO3)3 and H2L in DMF/H2O (4:1 vol./vol.) in a sealed scintillation vial at 80°C for three days.
A luminescent microporous metal-organic framework for the fast and reversible detection of high explosives
Lan, Anjian; Li, Kunhao; Wu, Haohan; Olson, David H.; Emge, Thomas J.; Ki, Woosoek; Hong, Maochun; Li, Jing

A highly luminescent microporous metal-org. framework, [Zn2(bpdc)2(bpee)] (bpdc = 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate; bpee = 1,2-bipyridylethene), was prepd., characterized by X-ray crystallog., and found to be capable of very fast and reversible detection of the vapors of the nitroarom. explosive 2,4-dinitrotoluene and the plastic explosive taggant 2,3-dimethyl-2,3-dinitrobutane through redox fluorescence quenching with unprecedented sensitivity.
Fluorescent metal-organic framework for selective sensing of nitroaromatic explosives
Gole, Bappaditya; Bar, Arun Kumar; Mukherjee, Partha Sarathi

Highly luminescent micrometre-sized fine particles of [Zn4O(L)2(H2O)3]-3DMA-3Et0H-6H20, a Zn(II) metal-org. framework (MOF) of a new π-electron rich tricarboxylate 5-(4-carboxyphenylethynyl)isophthalic acid dispersed in EtOH was demonstrated as a selective sensory material for the detection of nitroarom. explosives via a fluorescence quenching mechanism.
New Microporous Metal-Organic Framework Demonstrating Unique Selectivity for Detection of High Explosives and Aromatic Compounds
Pramanik, Sanhita; Zheng, Chong; Zhang, Xiao; Emge, Thomas J.; Li, Jing
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The authors report a highly luminescent metal-org. framework(MMOF), [Zn2(oba)2(bpy)]·DMA (I) H2oba is 4,4'-oxybis(benzoic acid); bpy is 4,4-bipyridine; DMA is N,N-dimethylacetamide, and its unique photoluminescence (PL) properties. the authors' studies on its guest-free form revealed unique fluorescence quenching and enhancement behavior upon exposure to the vapor of arom. compds. of group A with electron-withdrawing groups and group B with electron-donating groups, resp.  The results demonstrate the exceptional ability of the guest-free form of I to selectively detect explosives of different types (e.g., arom. DNT vs. nonarom. or aliph. dimethyldinitrobutane).  The origin of such an effect can be understood and explained from MO and band structure calcns. as well as a comparison of their electrochem. properties.  Clearly, the nature of the analyte mols. and the electronic structure and porosity of the MMOF all play key roles in the emission properties.
A colorimetric and fluorescent chemosensor for the detection of an explosive-2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP)
Peng, Yu; Zhang, Ai-Jiang; Dong, Ming; Wang, Ya-Wen

A fluorescent and colorimetric receptor (I) for specific recognition of TNP was described.  The origins of this remarkable affinity was disclosed by the crystal structure of corresponding host-guest complex I·TNP.
A highly stable dynamic fluorescent metal-organic framework for selective sensing of nitroaromatic explosives
Gong, Yun-Nan; Jiang, Long; Lu, Tong-Bu

A dynamic fluorescent metal-org. framework was constructed using triphenylene-2,6,10-tricarboxylate and Tb3+ as building blocks, which exhibits guest-responsive structural dynamism and selective sensing of nitroarom. explosives.
Highly Selective Detection of Nitro Explosives by a Luminescent Metal-Organic Framework
Nagarkar, Sanjog S.; Joarder, Biplab; Chaudhari, Abhijeet K.; Mukherjee, Soumya; Ghosh, Sujit K.

The compd. exhibited selective detection of TNP, even in the presence of other nitro compds. in both aq. and org. soln.  The selectivity is ascribed to electron and energy transfer mechanisms, as well as electrostatic interactions between TNP and the fluorophore.  Despite the limited water stability and the toxicity of the reported CdII MOF, the results demonstrate a promising approach to achieve highly selective TNP sensing in MOFs.  Thus, the luminescent porous MOFs with high water stability, large spectral overlap, and electrostatic interactions with TNP, could be promising candidates for practical TNP sensing by S. Ramachandra et al.(2011).  Finally, the present study provides a new insight into the design of MOF-based explosive sensors, which are likely to be useful under more realistic conditions in the near future.

Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability

By using the octadentate ligand tetrakis[(3,5-dicarboxyphenoxy)methyl]methane (H8L), a rare (4,8)-scu type microporous coordination polymer, [In2L][NH2Me2]2·(DMF)4(H2O)16, was synthesized and structurally characterized.  The compd. possesses an anionic three-dimensional open framework and exhibits permanent porosity with selective gas adsorption of CO2 over CH4.  It exhibited strong fluorescence emission upon excitation at RT, and a selective, efficient emission quenching response towards nitroarom. explosives.

Gong, Yun-Nan; Meng, Miao; Zhong, Di-Chang; Huang, Yong-Liang; Jiang, Long; Lu, Tong-Bu

A μ4-Cl bridged anionic sodalite-type porous metal-org. framework (Et2NH2)3[(Cu4Cl)3(TTCA)8]·26DEF was synthesized, in which Et2NH2+ can be exchanged by Li+ cations.  The results of gas measurements indicate that Et2NH2+ and Li+ are beneficial for methane and hydrogen storage, resp.
Three Zn(II)-triazole-H3btc complexes regulated by mixed ligands protonation upon stepwise crystallization
Yang, En-Cui; Liu, Zhong-Yi; Wang, Xiu-Guang; Batten, Stuart R.; Zhao, Xiao-Jun

By reaction of a zinc salt, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3btc) and 1,2,4-triazole (Htrz) under hydrothermal conditions, three mixed ligands protonation-dominated crystals, showing a 3-dimensional microporous framework for {[Zn2.5(trz)2(btc)(H2O)]·2H2O}n (1), a 3-dimensional pillared-layer structure for [Zn2.5(trz)2(Hbtc)(H2O)]n (2), and a 1-dimensional chain motif for {[Zn2.5(Htrz)2(Hbtc)(H2O)]·2H2O}n (3), were stepwise isolated by crystn. of the reaction mixt. and evapn. of the filtrates.
Fast detection of oxygen by the naked eye using a stable metal-organic framework containing methyl viologen cations

A stable porous metal-org. framework (MOF) contg. Me viologen cations exhibits reversible photochromic, thermochromic and fluorescence changes via host-guest interactions, and can be used for fast and selective detection of oxygen by naked eye recognition of color change within five seconds.

Journal of the American Chemical Society

The pore vol. and BET surface area of bio-MOF-1 (a), Zn8(ad)4(BPDC)6O·Me2NH2, is systematically modified via postsynthetic cation exchange with either tetramethylammonium, tetraethylammonium, or tetrabutylammonium cations to yield Zn8(ad)4(BPDC)6O·Me4N (b), Zn8(ad)4(BPDC)6O·2Et4N (c), and Zn8(ad)4(BPDC)6O·Bu4N (d), resp.  The impact that pore vol. and BET surface area have on CO2 capacity is evaluated, and it is found that materials with intermediate porosity (b and c) have the largest CO2 capacities under the conditions studied.

Zheng, Shou-Tian; Wu, Tao; Irfanoglu, Burcin; Zuo, Fan; Feng, Pingyun; Bu, Xianhui

A nested 3D-3D MOPF@MOPF cobalt-org. framework [(CH3)2NH2]10[Co2(IN)4(OAc)2][Co2(BTC)2(H2O)4]4[Co2(OH)(IN)3]4·4H2O (CPM-24, H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, HIN = isonicotinic acid) was prepd. and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and thermal gravimetric anal. Separation of CO2 from CH4 Using Mixed-Ligand Metal-Organic Frameworks
Bae, Youn-Sang; Mulfort, Karen L.; Frost, Houston; Ryan, Patrick; Punnathanam, Sudeep; Broadbelt, Linda J.; Hupp, Joseph T.; Snurr, Randall Q.

The adsorption of CO2 and CH4 in a mixed-ligand metal-org. framework (MOF) Zn2(NDC)2(DPNI) [NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate, DPNI = N,N'-di-(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalene tetracarboxydiimide] was studied using volumetric adsorption measurements and grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations.  The MOF was synthesized by 2 routes: 1st at 80° for 2 days with conventional heating, and 2nd at 120° for 1 h using microwave heating.  The 2 as-synthesized samples exhibit very similar powder x-ray diffraction patterns, but the evacuated samples show differences in nitrogen uptake.  From the single-component CO2 and CH4 isotherms, mixt. adsorption was predicted using the ideal adsorbed soln. theory (IAST).  The microwave sample shows a selectivity of ∼30 for CO2 over CH4, which is among the highest selectivities reported for this sepn.  The applicability of IAST to this system was demonstrated by performing GCMC simulations for both single-component and mixt. adsorption.
A unique magnesium-based 3D MOF with nanoscale cages and temperature dependent selective gas sorption properties
Huang, Yong-Liang; Gong, Yun-Nan; Jiang, Long; Lu, Tong-Bu

A porous Mg-based 3-dimensional metal-org. framework with unique nanoscale cages and 2-fold interpenetrating pcu nets, of [Mg16(PTCA)8(μ2-H2O)8(H2O)24(dioxane)8]·(H2O)13·(DMF)26 (1) [H4PTCA = pyrene-1,3,6,8-tetracarboxylic acid], was synthesized and characterized.  It shows gas-uptake capacities for N2, H2, O2 and CO2 at low temps. and selective adsorption of CO2 over O2 and N2 at room temp.
A novel (3,3,6)-connected luminescent metal-organic framework for sensing of nitroaromatic explosives
Sun, Libo; Xing, Hongzhu; Xu, Jin; Liang, Zhiqiang; Yu, Jihong; Xu, Ruren

A novel metal-org. framework [Cd3(CPEIP)2(DMF)3]·solvent (1) based on a neutral nonoxo triangular [Cd3(COO)6] secondary building unit (SBU), was synthesized under solvothermal conditions by using a rigid unsym. tricarboxylate ligand 5-((4-carboxyphenyl)ethynyl)isophthalic acid (H3CPEIP).  Single-crystal x-ray diffraction anal. reveals that compd. 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c.  The crystal structure exhibits a rare (3,3,6)-connected three-dimensional (3-D) framework with vertex symbol of (42.6)(43)(45.64.86).  The incorporation of CPEIP3+ into 1 gives rise to high luminescence in solid state.  The emission of micrometer-sized compd. 1 (1') dispersed in ethanol could be quenched efficiently by picric acid (PA), indicating that this compd. could be used as a chemosensor for detection of arom. explosives.

Zhang, Chengyi; Che, Yanke; Zhang, Zengxing; Yang, Xiaomei; Zang, Ling

Fluorescent nanoscale coordination polymers with cubic morphol. and long range ordered structure were fabricated and exhibited efficient sensing for both nitroarom. explosive and nitromethane due to large surface area to vol. ratio and strong binding affinity to explosive mols.
